title: Aristotle: Minor Works
description:
Aristotle: Minor Works
 Loeb Classical Library | January 1, 1936 | ISBN-10: 0674993381 | 528 pages | PDF | 12.54 MB

 Aristotle, great Greek philosopher, researcher, reasoner, and writer, born at Stagirus in 384 BCE, was the son of Nicomachus, a physician, and Phaestis. He studied under Plato at Athens and taught there (367ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“347); subsequently he spent three years at the court of a former pupil, Hermeias, in Asia Minor and at this time married Pythias, one of Hermeias's relations. After some time at Mitylene, in 343ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“2 he was appointed by King Philip of Macedon to be tutor of his teen-aged son Alexander. After Philip's death in 336, Aristotle became head of his own school (of 'Peripatetics'), the Lyceum at Athens. Because of anti-Macedonian feeling there after Alexander's death in 323, he withdrew to Chalcis in Euboea, where he died in 322.
